060106.answer: what i would do in that situation, and i have done this, is just make the song with the tools you have. remember the golden rule, which is that any song can be played using any set of instruments. that's one of the most exciting things about songs, is how many different ways you can do them. my song 'new canaan' is a great example of a song that absolutely did not feel like a keyboard song. when i wrote it it seemed like it should be someone strumming a mandolin or banjo or something. possibly a stupid idea to try to do it with keyboards, but, thinking of the golden rule, i realized that i can

060162.question: Many years ago I had fun memorizing a couple hundred digits of pi. I used 5-digit groups for the first hundred, but after that I found it was better to use variable-length groups -- easier to make up a story around them, harder to mix up the order, and so on. What's weird if I memorized them in my native language, which is not English, and it's really hard for me to recite the decimals in English. I have to pronounce them in my native language and translate the digits into English on the fly, which is hard to do at the same time. I memorized the sounds of the numbers, not the numbers themselves. I never decided to do that, it's just how I naturally did it. I wonder if other people memorized the shapes instead, and would have an easier time saying them in a different language by just visualizing the numbers instead of having to pronounce them internally. I'm not a musician but I'm curious as to how you learn a song. Probably you don't ju st recall the specific notes or chords, but some higher-order pattern? Is this something you can explain in simple words?
060162.answer: as long as i've heard a song more than 10 or 20 times, over the course of a few days, i automatically learn it and could not unlearn it. but the tricky part is if i have to learn (memorize) a song on short notice. for that, i absolutely just make a chart and then read it. i am pretty much bullet proof that way, in that case i would only have to hear a song once, i just write it down the first time. but in the rare case the director may say 'absolutely no reading' .... well ........ i'd be fucked. until the age of A.R. glasses

060371.question: u understand how craZy the cycles renderer is tho right? like, try to make a curved mirror in eevee. its basically impossible to make it fully reflective as far as i know
060371.answer: yes, and noisy, unless you wait 1,000 years. Update: i have waited 1,000 years and it's still noise city right. but, .... i am working with the absolute fastest computer on the market for my operating system, and there is still significant wait time just to even see what i'm working on. working blind is something i've just decided i'm not willing to do anymore. Additionally, .... i drew up a fairly simple scene (1 image! not even a video) with some lights and reflections, .... i set the sample# to 1000. waited quite awhile, and after all 1000 samples ..... still an absurdly high quantity of noise. not even close to being noise free. and still significant wait time. for ONE frame. a video contains at least 30 frames per second (and i would strongly prefer 60). yes eevee is frustrating and wacko when it comes to reflections and transparencies, and i still need serious help with it, but when all the factors are considered for Cycles, it's just no after no after no after no. If there is a computer in existence that can do Cycles renders instantaneously, i will spend my entire life savings on it. but i am under the impression that it is not there. The good news is, when put into perspective, Eevee is absolute lightyears ahead of where i've been before

060896.question: in might quit, when writing it, did you conceptualize it in 2 or in 3? because the entire song seems to have a 3:2 or 2:3 feel to it so i am keen to understand the process. in general when writing a song how does the time/feel factor into it? is it organic and known from the outset? does it come later?
060896.answer: it was immediately and always 4 quick groups of 3, with tempo around 102 bpm, each of those clicks having 3 subdivisions. can be written on paper as 12/8 or 4/4 with triplets, depending on whether you prefer to see a lot of dots or a lot of the number 3. even though i heard it clearly that way, i was aware that unfortunately 3x2 can get screwed and heard wrong if you're not very careful in how you portray the rhythms. did not want anyone to hear it as a 3/4 lullaby feel. did everything i could to ensure you hear it as a 4/4 or 12/8 west-african feel. the fact that you are not sure is actually a sign that i failed. tried to put solid clanks on the downbeats whenever possible, in addition to probably providing a firm count-off at the beginning fully, entirely yes

060978.question: i'm not 11.22.19 8:55 pm , but kind of in the same situation. i have lost my creativity and ability to talk to people throughout the last year. feeling like my life is falling apart. i try to find joy in socializing again, or at least some sort of escape from reality. i really want to make other people happy, inspire them somehow, though i can't even help myself at the moment. would you kindly suggest something?
060978.answer: what always works for me in those situations is to start expressing myself in any way possible, whether it's written text, improvised music, or spoken words, even just discussing and anlyzing the situation. that's just because stirring up mental energy is the main way that i function and feel alive. it also gives me a lot of extra comfort to also know that i am documenting those expressions as a souvenir of the struggle. for me, that always works. i often recommend the same thing to other people, but actually i just realized that maybe not everyone else is exactly the same as me

061263.question: Okay, here's my situation.... I have been on a bonkers schedule for a little under a year, and in that time I have conquered a considerable chunk of the observable universe thanks to the schedule. It really drags you along and makes you get things done. But I'm thinking of going off the schedule, partially because I just rediscovered the unobservable universe and really wanna go crazy and do something different in there. On one hand, this is exciting beyond the belief. Dropping the schedule feels like freedom. (I'm also pretty tired from making content daily, so I love the idea of a change of pace.) On the other hand, I haven't been off-schedule in a long time, and the schedule itself gave me the initial jolt of energy I needed to get going, so I fear the lack of direction/motivation that (sometimes) comes from having no schedule. You've done all sorts of schedules and non-schedules... any advice?

061388.question: You responded to a question about tuning systems a while back. The asker wanted to know if you'd ever tried tuning completely in just intonation. You said it's a noble endeavor, but ultimately it's impossible; you couldn't even get a full major scale out of the harmonic series, much less a working system of chromatic harmony. I've realized something which could go a long way towards solving this problem - I've even composed/arranged some nice music using this concept. (It is by no means my original idea, btw.) Your problem was that you tried to create a major scale (C major, if I recall) in which each scale degree was only tuned one way, regardless of its 'function'. For example, F would always be the same pitch, whether it was the 3rd of a D minor chord or the 7th of a G7 chord. The way I started thinking about just intonation tuning is this: all harmony diatonic to C major can be derived from the harmonic serie s of Bb (minus 4ข, because C, in this case, is defined as the 9th harmonic of Bb). In the C overtone series, we can get a very nice version of the C major triad (1st, 3rd, and 5th harmonics), the G major triad (3rd, 9th, and 15th harmonics), the E minor triad (3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics), and the B diminished triad (15th, 9th, and 21st harmonics). In order to get the three remaining triads, you need to use some 'undertones' of C - notes for which C is an overtone. I thought about it like this - if we get C major and E minor triads from the C harmonic series - we can just transpose down a (harmonic) perfect fifth to get F major and A minor triads. Then we can transpose down another perfect fifth to get the D minor triad (3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics of Bb). Since F-2ข and C are both overtones in the Bb-4ข harmonic series, and since each overtone has a harmonic series of its own (which is still part of the original harmonic series), we can say that a ll harmo ny diatonic to C major can come from the Bb-4ข overtone series and sound great. However, to sound good, notes need to be tuned differently depending on what member they are in a chord. For example, the D minor triad in C sounds great on its own when tuned as the 3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics of Bb-4ข. But the D minor triad can also be found within a G9 chord. In this case, a different tuning will be way more consonant - as the 3rd, 7th, and 9th harmonics of G+2ข (which is the 3rd harmonic of C and the 27th harmonic of Bb-4ข). If I remember correctly, this is how you tried to tune a D minor triad a while back - it sounds consonant in the context of a G9 chord, but not in the normal context of a D minor chord. I realize this is not so practical for live keyboard or fretted instruments, but it's been great for retuning recorded music or composing in a DAW. Thoughts?
061388.answer: it probably doesn't help that i've never seen this symbol before: ข, but essentially, what i discovered boils down to this, speaking in the key of C: the very nature of notes like D, F, G, and A, ... when all used together.... those all need to have certain relationships to each other simultaneously, which is actually impossible. the only way this 'secondary' chord seems to want to work is when it actually feels like all these relationships are true: the F and D have to have a good relationship, the F and A have to have a good relationship, the D and G have to have a good relationship, and the F and C, ... and the G and C, ...... and what i came to discover was that it's actually this subtlely impossible nature that gives this chord such a longing need to go back 'home' to the 1 chord. kind of blew my mind. i explained all of this as well as i ever possibly could, right here, and like i said, it gave me a deeper appreciation and validation for the 12 tone equal temperment system than i ever thought possible, and i have never questioned it since

061876.question: How would you recommend I start learning about something that I may be passionate about without dropping it? Every time I want to start to commit to something that would take dedication and time seems unappealing to me after the first couple of days. I'm just asking around literally anywhere, I just wanted to see if you had any insight, thanks.
061876.answer: you must zero in on the exact moment that sparked your interest. if you think about it you can usually pinpoint it. like, .... i was in the park and i saw a certain crazy tree. and it made me think 'wow ........ i must learn all about trees... everything about trees! it will be so much fun!' so you go and start learning all about every tree and suddenly it feels wicked boring and you don't remember why you are doing it. well, guess what, you gotta go back to that one tree you saw because whatever it is you thought you wanted, it was in THAT tree. you must pinpoint the original source of your interest, and it can usually be narrowed down to a very specific exact moment

061891.question: i'm writing a research paper about your christmas isn't real video and i'm desperately analyzing it
061891.answer: it was written in 2 parts. the 1st line (up to 'jesus'), and the rest. like many songs i write nowadays, it is written as if by 2 different people holding 2 different job titles, the Starter and the Finisher. the Starter's job is to come up with a line that could be made into a song, then hand it over to the Finisher saying 'here, you fuckin deal with it.' and then create more starter ideas for more songs. that's all the Starter does. just start songs and throw them into the starter bank. and the Finisher's job is to take the half baked crap that the Starter hands over, and find a way to deal with it. there is actually a very important 3rd job title which i haven't mentioned, who decides which one of the Starter's ideas to give to the Finisher. that would be the Selector. this is to ensure that the Finisher is not impeded by the horrific doubts of 'questioning the Selection'

061893.question: i feel like you're very quick to put the kabosh on analogous thinking, stepping in with an implication to remind the asker that the subjects in question are not entirely alike at all, and are both wonderful and terrible in their own ways. You do this with common structures for questions, as well. I have a great respect for it, because it feels like you're stopping generalization and forcing people to look even harder at things. However, I am in a cognitive science class, and it is teaching me that analogy is fairly specific to humans, and it might be what has allowed us to advance beyond other species. We can apply learned information in a highly abstract way to many facets of our lives when we recognize similar structure, whereas other animals cannot. So now I am torn! What do you make of this?

061940.question: alright, so, i got this song idea that im struggling with. the intro, just basically slow moody noodling on piano, is fine. then it moves into a syncopated staccato feel in D minor and i want to find a section to bridge between that and a less-momentum-y chorus-esque section, still in D minor. I also am trying to write lyrics for the whole song (on the subject of loneliness and isolation coz thats the concept of the album) and am struggling with that too. do you have any advice for overcoming my musical and poetic writers block or any avenues i could explore that i havent already?
061940.answer: although i know the meaning of all the terms you used, still the funny thing about music is there is still no way for me to actually have any idea how your song actually goes. what i might dare to recommend, and i recommend this all too often because it has worked very well for me, is try to write much shorter songs so you can more quickly learn the possibilities. even just the amount of time you've spent giving a verbal description of the song, is enough time to lose momentum of the process. need to go much quicker, more carefree. and for now try shorter songs so you can explore the entire process faster and get more of an idea of what the possibilities can be. and beware that trying to explain a song to someone who hasn't heard it, very often kills it

062019.question: 12.4.19 4:25 pm please talk more about reality tunnels i keep thinking about them
062019.answer: 2 people might look at the same picture, and one person thinks it's "a cat next to a moose", and the other person might think the picture is "a moose next to a cat" ...... our entire world is filled with nano seconds and pixels and colors, ... too many to actually list them all. So in order to actually describe anything, we have to take shortcuts, and make our own simplified interpretation of what we think we saw. when Time is involved, it complicates it even more. because each interpreter might be choosing different moments in time to be the most important. To make any sense of the world at all, we must describe things in ways that we can comprehend, rather than actually listing the location and status of every molecule at every point in time. Because of this, every person may seem to see the world differently ..... not because they actually see or hear any differently, but because when faced with infinite data points, there are infinite different ways to make sense of them, or choose which ones to even look at, and when

062086.question: hey, just curious if you remember what it was like transitioning into writing the roadmap for songs before you record them, assuming you did it a different way before. like how did you learn?
062086.answer: not really a transition.... i've tried both, and when i don't write it first, it just doesn't have the freedom to go where it wants to go. As i'm saying this now, i can see that it appears backwards, but the reason is because when you're recording a song there are lot of instruments and parts to deal with, so you can't very easily change the way the song goes, on a whim. I've found that it's a much greater advantage when you write the song before anything is recorded, because you can make the song go anywhere, on a whim. you just write it there and it goes there. in other words, writing is not like writing multiple instruments. i don't write the instruments, i write the *song*. which consists of melody+lyric+chords, all the way through, and knowing the exact tempo. The process of translating that into instruments only happens once the song is written. it's probably a lot like animating a cartoon. it's pretty hard to improvise a cartoon. you kind of have to know how it goes before you do it. you CAN however, improvise a cartoon by acting it out, improvised. then based on the recorded improv, make the cartoon. similarly, a song could be made by improvising it using 1 instrument and voice, and then constructing the arrangement based on that recording. i forgot the question

062269.question: it feels like most people consume content ranter than create it. Did you transition from consuming content to creating it? If so, how do you think you made this transition?
062269.answer: yes i was way too confused to do it, because there were too many combinations of possibilities nested within possibilities, i was drowning in infinity. but eventually i got so desperate to do it that i just started, in any way i could. but i was still drowning in infinity. so i tried to talk it out. and i was making a lot of progress, but i was still drowning in infinite ideas and ideas of ideas ..... but as i started to create more raw/improvised materials, it gradually shifted toward drowning in infinite raw improvised content. a similar but slightly more constructive predicament. then just continued along in this way, still being desperately overwhelmed until finally, way after i thought it was too late, i tried again. and was still too confused, and failed. then i thought it was REALLY over. then i immediately started a website and rigorous weekly production schedule and never looked back. i'm still drowning in infinity, but i now have quite a sizeable arsenal of remedies for it. i forgot the question

062275.question: how would you call this chord? G-Bb-Db-F i'd write it as Gdim7, cause you have the G diminished chord and you're adding the minor 7th. however, for some reason ingrained in tradition, Gdim7 usually means G-Bb-Db-E, while i think the chord i want would be called Gm7-5 or something. this is one of those cases where i just want to ditch the established names and just go with what makes most sense to me, but i'd like to be able to understand when other people write music too.
062275.answer: depends where the bass is right yes, in some communities it is called that. elsewhere it tends to be called "G half diminished" which is written with a symbol similar to the diminished symbol (small circle) but with a slash through the circle i would recommend calling it Gm7b5 or G half diminished. i suppose the reason it's called half diminished is because the 5th is diminished and the 7th is not. i think in the traditional view, for major/minor intervals, 'diminished' actually means an additional halfstep flat. so a diminished 7th actually technically is the same notes as a major 6th. none of this is really important unless you like it

062276.question: do you have a keyboard you can recommend for beginner? i thought about getting a fancy one but now i'm considering the very basic, like a baby piano with the colorful keys
062276.answer: the most important thing is this: the keyboard needs to know how loud you pressed the note. Some extremely extremely toy keyboards actually cannot tell the difference between a loud and a soft note, so all the notes sound the same volume. this means that you will sound like a beginner forever, even if you are good. so at the bare minimum, you must get a keyboard that knows the difference between a loud and a soft note. this is called "dynamic sensitive". a simple way to test this is: press a note very quietly, and then press it very loud. see if there is actually a difference in volume. i promise you, if you get a keyboard that does not have dynamic sensitivity, you will sound like a beginner for the rest of your life and not know why

062295.question: Hey Bill, I am writing an essay about you in my AP language class. I have found your video diaries in the reality section of this site really helpful, but I was hoping you could answer two questions. Thank you for everything you do. Here goes: 1. Your music has been described as jazz-pop. In your opinion, is that a fitting description for your work or would you prefer a different term or no term at all? 2. Have your writing methods changed over the years? If so, how?
062295.answer: categorizing music into genres reminds me of categorizing people into races. it causes me to feel strange and uncomfortable music is such a strangely powerful thing, capable of such wonder and mischief, that if anyone tries to pin it down or label it, i would have every expectation that the music will find means to thwart that label with great excitement. it happens again and again and again, and this is probably the most important quality that music has, or any art in general. or the conscious human mind in general. surprise me yes i used to only know how to write totally in order (beginning to end), and in the same exact session as when i started it. nowadays, i not only know how to pick up a stray idea that was handed to me (from myself in an earlier time) and professionally figure out what to do with it, but also i know how to do this even if (god forbid) the idea actually belongs in the middle of the song

062309.question: why do you upload reality videos years after they are first recorded?
062309.answer: not just upload. select and edit. it allows me to make them better, because i know how the story turns out, so i know which things to choose, knowing what has the strongest relevance. and it also allows me to reveal behind the scenes details without giving away future projects. For example, if i released a reality video using journal audio recorded today, you might (for example) hear me talking about how i am definitely building an animatronic giraffe, and i am very excited about it. Well, guess what, if i release something like that, 2 things might happen. 1 is, i might ultimately fail at building the giraffe and have to abandon the project, in which case it would look very embarassing for me, because everyone would know i failed. And also it might be possible that someone could steal my design for animatronic giraffe and rush to beat me at my own idea. That's a fictional example, but here's an actual example, of a reality video that was released relatively soon after it was recorded -- probably recorded soon after history of japan was released, and the reality video was released probably 3 months later. The subject of the video was about making a music album. I thought, at the time, that i was going to make a music album, of songs. I thought that was a good idea at the time. but since then, i have changed my opinion and now i strongly prefer single songs. So those reality videos talking about making an album look pretty silly now, and they also incite a lot of people to ask "where's the album, what happened to the album", but there is no album. If i had waited a bit longer before releasing journals from that time, i surely would not have chosen the album discussions, and would have gone with something else instead

062344.question: Hey Bill, I need your help. I have a bunch of things I have to do like studying for history, setting up my strat guitar, putting together tracks, tracking acoustic guitar, vocals, drums, editing some songs, making a short film, try to make a live music video, etc. But then I see this list and I can't decide which one to do first and somehow become overwhelmed and lazy, so I procrastinate. How do I get my work done?
062344.answer: get an audio recording device, press record, get on the computer, learn how to take screen shots if you can't already, and start brainstorming, and type out the list. take screenshots as you go (and say "screenshot" each time you do) so anyone who finds your recordings in the future can follow along with you. (screen recording is even better, if you do that just make sure at the beginning you say "sync" and clap your hands once). congratulations, now you are on TV, which is fun, and you're not allowed to be lazy on tv. so keep discussing things until you figure out what order the list should be in. Then once you have that, it should be much easier to do things in the order you have endorsed. This advice sounds outrageous now that i say it, but that's the exact and only way it works for me

062588.question: Have you ever noticed how impractical the English language truly is? So many words look exactly the same yet mean completely different things, or maybe only slightly different things, and sometimes the same word can both mean the plural and the singular. No language is 'easy' to learn per se, but some are easier to learn than others, this one is probably on the harder side of things. The problem is, this language may be impractical as all hell, but it's also the only language that can describe certain things, that other languages just can't do or say, that the idea alone, that combination of meanings, was completely out of their realm of possibility, and that is fascinating. How do you feel about languages? It doesn't have to be about this specific topic, if you don't want to.

062716.question: i don't think you and i have the same process or the same goals musically but i am still curious about your opinion. i'm putting together a set of songs that are basically a religious service like there are liturgical functions for each one except the religion is fictional and this is a sort of alternate universe where everybody knows what to do in this kind of service so it's gotta sound both deeply ingrained and spontaneous so there are no instruments it's all singing, stomping and clapping. the constraint i gave myself to keep this project from taking 8 khgpillion years was that every single first-track take has to be improvised and then i stack more improvising as reactions on top of that track. fastest one (there should be about 16 when i am done, rn i have 5) took 2 hours, slowest one took 2 weeks because the initial improv was both extremely irregular and extremely precise and i had to basically learn it to improvise over and react to it in a way tha t sounded good to me. FINALLY A QUESTION FOR YOU do you think if you engaged in this sort of improvise-stack-more-no-precomposing-allowed that you'd let yourself get more weird and less polished or would you allow so much re-improvising that it eventually just became a kind of postcomposition? i am having some trouble with the bits of the improvs i don't think are as successful; should i allow chop-ups or is the one-initial-take rule a good one? i thought i could get this done faster if i hobbled my perfectionism by specifying ONLY spontaneous improv allowed, but there are so many ways to elude the spirit of that law and no external deadline requiring i actually do it any faster. what u think
062716.answer: it sounds like a good idea in theory, but i've tried that sort of thing and it definitely does not work for me. what does work however, is to do a lot of improv and use certain bits for writing purposes. what also works well is to try to write very fast

062783.question: 12.13.19 10:12 pm fair enough, i guess i believe you but it's a little difficult. have you always had this skill or was it something you had to learn? of not taking things personally and not getting angry at people for doing dumb or dangerous stuff, driving or otherwise?
062783.answer: i actually always wondered why most people are so insanely hypocritical while driving. it seems to me that 90% of things that drivers get mad at other drivers for, are actually insanely reasonable things, that they've certainly done themselves. like for example, car 1 is making a right turn. but there happens to be someone crossing a crosswalk, blocking their right turn. car 2, behind car 1, is freaking out and going apeshit at car 1 for 'just waiting there'. but there is a perfectly good reason car 1 is waiting there. they are doing a classic maneuver called 'making a right turn without killing the walking person.' Every single day i watch drivers freak out at other drivers for doing perfectly good and totally normal things. i did not have to learn how not to be angry at them for it, but i am still learning how such anger and shortsightedness could occur

063349.question: How do you get the courage and express to do the things in your mind? Every time I start I keep thinking "this is not good enough" and stop.
063349.answer: it seems like the fact that you are asking this question means you want to express yourself. so the courage will be there, if that's what you want. the rest is just spending time with it. and remember the golden rule, which is that at every level of experience, even the highest levels, there is a certain element of 'here is a pile of crap, you will like this crap.' what the heck, i do that every day, what with telling people my favorite cereal is marbles. or maybe some people may view that answer as just the perfect answer. at every level of art there is a certain degree of 'World Renowned Artist Presents: Crap.' Look at even the most well respected pieces of art. You can see how they're crap if you put yourself in the artist's shoes. (is anyone going to think this is good, or is it just crap). So go ahead and adopt that mindset early, and that should allow you to have a nice rebellious good time, in the meantime, while you are gradually and unassumingly accumulating genuine experience, which will inevitably happen over time

063385.question: Hey, can you share useful prime factorization techniques?
063385.answer: sure. to check if 7267 is divisible by 7, we can knock off the 7s (26) now we just have to check if 26 is divisible by 7, and it's clearly not because your local multiples of 7 are 21 and 28, not 26. so if 26 is not divisible by 7, we know by extension that 7267 is not either. because to get from 26 to 7267, you have to multiply by 10, add 7, and add 7000. multiplying by 10 will never change whether something is a multiple of 7. and adding more multiples of 7 will never change whether or not something is a multiple of 7. so if 26 is not a multiple of 7, then you know 7267 is not either. congratulations, now you are supposed to check 7267 for 11, assuming you have already checked for 3 which is much easier and i assume you already know how to do

063699.question: Why is there no b sharp?
063699.answer: because music generally uses families of notes that are not all equally related to each other. the piano, however, uses a full system of notes where each note is equally related to the next, but it's layed out in a way that you can easily skip some of them. the letter names of the notes were based on skipping some of them, because that's generally the trick to getting music to happen. so the spaces in between are called sharps and flats, but like i was saying before, to get that good music sound you wanna skip some notes but not all. and the letters are put on there based on having skipped some notes but not all. so some letter notes are direct next door neighbors (no sharp/flat in between). To explain that in a more real life setting, if you made a system of only 6 letters, with sharps placed between all of them, you would find that playing on only the plain letter keys would produce a very dizzy disoriented sound, akin to a time-warp or flashback scene. but instead the way the letters are actually arranged, this way you can just play the plain letter keys and automatically get something very friendly sounding, like joy to the world, right out of the box

063703.answer: i agree entirely well, when you put it that way, i am instantly reminded of the way cars changed the horse industry. and the way computers changed the paper industry. or any other transformation in human history. given the ubiquity of human transformation, over the centuries, it would feel hopelessly shortsighted to claim "oh no" and "it's bad" and "too bad the world sucks now", because people have been trying to say that for millennia and it's never been true. change is strange but it's also fun and good, and has the best intentions

063756.question: umm. 12.25.19 1:27 am there is b-sharp. you can cleverly teach all you want, but SEVERAL of my favorite preludes and fugues in Bach's well tempered clavier have countless b-sharps
063756.answer: to explain to a beginner all the way up to the land of B# and Cb would probably be impossible. as it is, my paragraph was probably too long and they probably went to sleep during it. it's like, first you'd have to explain why B and C are only a half step apart instead of a whole step. that's probably weird enough for someone to get their head around. the B# issue would probably only become relevant after a person has fully absorbed the B-C half step issue. but to continue, which i don't know why i would because you must already know, but to continue, sometimes on paper you will see B# which is actually the same note as C. so the next question a person might ask is "why the heck would you ever say B# instead of C" which is a question i'm sure i have answered several times before, such as 11.23.18 11:28 pm, or 5.22.17 12:59 pm actually it looks like that second one actually takes you all the way through, so that's probably what i should have said in order to avoid being called on the complaint line

063885.question: Any idea why some chords make us feel sad, and other seem happy? Is is cultural or universal? Or maybe it's a property not only of the chord, but of the surrounding music as well? I'd love to hear your ideas about this, if you don't mind.
063885.answer: that's one of life's great mysteries i am pretty sure it is mostly universal yes that's definitely true i have studied this at great length, and i still don't have any great answers. what i can say is that our entire world is based on times, timing, and relationships between frequencies. music is able to deal with all those things, completely raw. so that may explain why it has the powers it has, but still doesn't explain exactly how they work. to figure that out would be to truly figure out the nature of consciousness, which by its very nature is extremely flexible and has a mind of its own (is a mind of its own). which might explain why it can be so impossible to find any rules for it

063894.question: how do i stop fiddling around on my midi keyboard i got for christmas and cut straight to recording actual songs. also do you wanna high five?
063894.answer: i know the exact solution that works for this, and this turned out very important for me: you must write the song first, without touching the keyboard. preferably in a different location. if you don't have any language to conceive of music on paper while away from an instrument, you can develop one, or, you can get another instrument which you only use for writing, and a recording device and a text file to help manage the writing. figure out how the song goes, all the way through, before recording. you don't have to know every little instrumental part, but you should know the melody lyric chords and the exact length and road map and exact tempo all the way to the end. i find it very important to tell you this because i have been in your exact situation and this was the exact solution that saved me i will think about it

063988.question: so how are you working around that export issue that prevented you from using blender in the past?
063988.answer: that's already mostly solved. the best way i was able to wrap my head around it is to always export the image sequence to the temp folder. let it overwrite, and as part of the video exporting procedure, i convert the image sequence into a video file, which automatically names itself based on the date and time. an extra challenge is that my preferred software for that sort of thing was quicktime 7 which is also gone. so i am using ffmpeg instead, and i have automated the whole procedure to a single button press using keyboard maestro, which is also what generates the dated file names. i still have no idea how anyone else manages files/exports from blender, but that is the way i am currently doing it. it's worth mentioning that the other tremendous hangup i had with blender in 2016 was the lack of save prompts, and the constant risk of so easily losing the project. but i was thrilled to see that save prompts are there now. and i also used keyboard maestro to get even more robust autosaves

064106.question: alright (for context) i have seven groups of sticky notes that i use to document all of my ideas. six groups are for each tangible project idea that i have, and the seventh is a grouping of every random thought that i've had which i can hopefully utilize in some creative way. now, the hard part is that i want to make something from these ideas, but i can't decide which one to use first. this isn't helped by the fact that i constantly get new thoughts and creative ideas every day for each project randomly. how would you deal with this?
064106.answer: first of all i think you might be better off digitally, with computer files. because they are easier to store and manage without making a mess. ok, so, keep updating your 'random' category. this will be your good friend, as you get new ideas. that is fine. there is another job title which is going through the 'random' category, selecting one, and figuring out how to turn it into a more tangible project idea, like the others. What i would suggest to you is this: use a random number generator to choose a number based on how many projects there are, plus 1 for the random ideas category (so currently this number would be 7). i can recommend random dot org for that. set the range from 1 to 7. (also you must assign numbers to the categories, so you know what the numbers mean). if it lands on the random category (7), then tangify 3 random ideas into actual project ideas, and use random dot org to select which ones from that category to do. then go back and do another random selection again (with a higher number this time, because hopefully you will have added more projects). Here's what i recommend: you must finish the project that is selected. If this seems too overwhelming, then I would recommend doing shorter projects until you are more confident in the procedure. some people are ok with bouncing between projects, but every time i've tried this, it simply turns into a license to escape. so these are my best recommendations

064191.question: 12.31.19 6:03 pm this is so interesting. I am wondering tho, what does the 36, -1, (\d|\D)(?=,), and x%n% mean? so interesting
064191.answer: 36 is the range of the random number picked. has to be between 0 and 35. it's going to be converted to letters/numbers. so that's how many choices there are (26 letters, and 10 numbers). the '-1' means you start the variable "n" at -1. the (\d|\D)(?=,) is regex to search for every letter/number with a comma after. the x%n% means literally the letter x followed by whatever value n currently is. so if n is 5 then x%n% would be x5

064291.question: Consciousness can be kinda weird when you think about it, it is also very hard to explain, like, It's an active brain that is aware of itself kinda? But consciousness kinda feels like it takes place outside of the brain, like an extension of itself, the collective whole. It is absolutely mystifying to me. Though when you go to sleep, you have then 'lost' consciousness. Well, where did it go? I'm assuming that this means that everything was sort of 'separate' for a while, which makes sense, because a lot of the brain majorly either slows down or stops completely while asleep, and thus the whole is not there. But it's death that is weird. When you sleep, it can feel like an instant from when you fell asleep to when you woke, but when you die, that instant of being conscious again will (in theory) never come. You won't know anything, you won't be anything, and it's that thought that scares me. And it's that thought in which pushes me to slow down on lif e and re ally focus on the parts I enjoy rather than trying to do things that will get me material things, I don't want a job, I just want to make things, and I just want to be remembered, at least in some capacity, at least for a little while. Sorry if I rambled on for a bit too long there, but I was just wondering if you had any sort of insight or if you have any similar ideas/thoughts at all? Thanks for reading.
064291.answer: that's true you're not the only one how do you figure you've presented various different ideas here, getting mind blown by the idea of concsiousness, yes that i can relate to wholly. you infered somehow that it's the end of all consciousness when you die, and i didn't really gather where you were coming from with that. and you said you want to be remembered, yes i can relate to that, as i think all of us can

064346.question: Right now in Australia we're dealing with our worst fires in recorded history and have lost almost 500 million animals and quite a few people, including volunteer firefighters. Over 14 million acres have been burnt. That's twice the size of Belgium. It's scary and hard to comprehend. I'm lucky enough not to be affected but I feel dreadful not being able to help. I've managed to donate $130 dollars but it feels like nothing. It wouldnt even scratch the surface. It might put fuel in 2 cars with small tanks. It can't buy even a cheap firefighting pump, or hardly any livestock feed, or other necessities like that. It brings me to tears knowing I'm capable of so little because of my lack of money. Sometimes I wish I were rich, purely for the ability to fucking help more and make an actual difference. Sorry, I just had to vent a bit. I can't express these feelings to people around me because ffs, these selfish issues are nothing compared with w hat the people affected are dealing with and it's childish of me to think like this. Wtf can I do? I'm just one person.
064346.answer: what we might need even more than money, is inventiveness. in that sense, you have all the wealth it takes to make potentially the most valuable contribution ever made. all the money in the world is useless without ideas

064362.question: so for the longest time i've been stuck voicing chords like a baby on piano. meaning like if there were a Cmaj7 on a leadsheet i would instinctively play it like (C,E,G,B) in the left hand AND (C,E,G,B) in the right hand. It seems kind of dumb but my entire understanding of music and how i made sense of harmony came from root voicing block chords. But it's a serious rut. because obviously listening to your music there's a whole other thing to it which i interpret as "sparse-ness". Meaning EVERY note can MATTER and hold serious weight leading into wherever it goes. I just suppose this anyway...But for Years i couldn't begin to understand the logic to it. Meanwhile, I plowed through a harmony book. learned about all these cool chords Outside of the major scale that relate to the major scale. and implement them as well as fun time signatures into my work in a way that was organic and good. but i still do the dumb chord thing. and so like a year ago to h opefully evolve and understand why I needed to change I started transcribing pop songs i enjoyed, completely. even maracas for like one upbeat on a single measure. So I think my ear is getting better because of that. i mean it might be ridiculous. considering i'm sure even the players for "running on empty"-jackson browne were looking at Much simpler charts than what they actually played. but i insist on doing it. Anyway! So all this time passes in my development and i still feel like i'd immediately fall face first if i were let out in the real world because of the chord thing. throughout all this time i would ask people "how do i get out of this habit, how do i change?" and they said almost every time "...just do it? there's literally nothing stopping you." which seemed kind of asshole-ish. cuz it didn't really seem like advice. but lo and behold, last night i just "did it" and i can't explain how i "did it". i just did. the comping/voice leading was beautiful. it was honestly jus t a deci sion to do it. and it kind of pisses me off because i could've done this THE WHOLE TIME!! but i literally can't explain it. it's ethereal. something fundamental in ME must've changed, or something. have you ever experienced anything like this? not even just music but like being in a situation where "there's a thing you want to do, you know what it is you gotta do, but something peculiarly vague in your bones is holding you back"?
064362.answer: ah yes, it is definitely fun to realize that way of thinking is mostly a myth holy cow it's worse than i thought yeah but it doesn't take long to get up. you'd be surprised how quickly, once you get out there actually for that issue, at least the one you first mentioned, i definitely have some tangible hints, althought it seems like you've already been through it, based on your experience with song books, etc yes there are many things like that, sort of on the periphery. meanwhile there are the things that are front and center which are usually the subject of a flaming freight train. typically the biggest thing that holds me back on the most important stuff is the vastly infinite quantities of configurations, iterations, permutations, transliterative concatenations, .,.,.,,.,,.,

To that I say, how do they know.. I mean humans seem to have this drive to be remembered, its completely unreasonable when you think of it, but isnt everything reasonable? For example we have the desire to reproduce in order to extend the impact of our species, maybe the end goal is escaping the collapsing universe? who knows, but thats not my point, my point is that if we have this strong urge to be remembered, maybe there is some deeper meaning to it, one we cant grasp? perhaps this life is just the first stage, or maybe its a stage after a previous one, and the previous one impacted this one, we were rewarded with different skills because of our previo us stage s, maybe this cycle never ends.. i dont know.. i like deeper questions how about you? any imput on this one? good luck friend on earth

064518.question: My music teacher hasn't taught us about how to read music or anything because she thinks we did it in primary school, we weren't. So I'm feeling extremely confused about music because of that, and I don't really understand anything I find on the internet. Do you have any sources that you'd recommend?
064518.answer: i don't know any specific sources, but i can be a source. if you want to learn to read notation, i will probably want to start you off with rhythms. time goes forward from line to line. the first thing you want to do is understand beats. it's just like a steady ticking clock that ticks along with the beat all the way through a song. listen to some songs, and see if you can tap your foot along to the beat. also be aware that music notation flows left to right, and then down to the next line. left to right, next line, left to right, etc. just like the words on this page. let me know when you have found the beat for some of your favorite songs. if you look at the cowbell part for the second verse of my song 'hallelujah', that is an example of the beat. you might say i am hitting the cowbell 'on the beat'. it usually stays the same for the whole song. the songs you pick may have a faster or slower beat from that, but most of them will probably be slightly faster, because that song has a relatively slow tempo. see if you can find the beat for some of your favorite songs, then i will see if i can tell you what's necessary to start understanding what happens on the page

064550.question: What is the best thing to do when you are stuck during a creative process?

064760.question: Hello and thank you. It's all a lot. What do you think about stuff? There's both a lot of it and somehow, not enough. When I can't deal with all the stuff, I feel better after I get stuff out, which usually requires making more stuff. And that just feels like what all of everything is made up of and we're all stuff making more stuff and other stuff. 064982.question: I am currently in the early stages of recording all my ideas (mostly writing projects, some non-writing projects) into timestamped text files; I have configured a immediate shortcut to do this, etc. I worried I am just recording complete garbage and that it will be impossible to sift through later, not even certain how exactly I will be picking and actioning these things. Are there any recommendable checks, measures, bits of discipline to make this whole process workable?
064982.answer: i'll tell you the way i went through it. my plan, when i was at the exact same stage as you, is to go through them in order. talk/discuss (record the discussion also) the item at hand and determine where it's at. discuss its origins, discuss your first reactions, impressions, think about its origins, .... contemplate its place in the universe , ... and imagine whether you think it's worth it for it to exist / be finished. if you genuinely determine it's worth it, then start pursuing the next steps. determine what piece of it you have. is it the middle? beginning? something else? if it's the beginning, then your next task is to come up with the next part. this is best done by sheer runthroughs, and cut off right at the end, and listen very closely if the next bit will present itself. it can also be good to think process of elimination. what do you know it will and won't be? (categorically). i.e. will be a zebra/pony ride, or will it not be a zebra/pony ride. etc.... that could narrow it down. and again, continue raw runthroughs and cut off at end. If the initial idea was in the middle, that's probably just a lot of process of elimination. Once you have a significant development done on that item, document/date your progress and move to the next one. Then, aftar about 6 months of doing this (writing a little bit on each item) ... then, organize all the items into a new order, by % completed. appraise them all by % complete you think they are (estimation) and re-sort the list. Then, look at the top group (90 to 99% completed). choose (genuinely, without random assistance) 1 item from that group. Your next task is to finish the writing on that item. when i say 'finish the writing' i mean know how it goes from beginning to end. know all the bars, how many bars, all melody/lyric, chords, ... whatever constitutes your idea of a song in your mind, finish it so you know all that. mark it done. then go to the next group (80 to 89%). do the same thing. pick one, finish it. keep going like this, to the 70s, 60s, etc, all the way down, finishing (writing) 1 item per group. go around the group 2 or 3 times. Now, it's time to record. take the entire list, it doesn't matter what order, but preferably chronological. go through the list, (this will take a day or two) for each song, check how the song goes (properly consult all your documentation for it, read it, play it, check out all samples, etc. fully check how it goes, even if you think you vaguely remember. look it up for real.) then decide 'would i be excited to record this' or 'would i not be excited to record this'? your list of 'yes's can be as long as you want, so don't worry about 'to the exclusion of all other' just yet, just ask yourself would you be excited on some planet in some universe to record this one. if yes, then add it to a list (this is the semi-finals for recording selection list). Continue going through the entire master items list and add all the ones you would be excited to do. Then, as soon as you've gone through the entire list, IMMEDIATELY numberize the semi-finals list and make a random selection (using computer, like random.org. It is important that you do this immediately when completing the semi-finals list. Do not go around a second time. whenever i've gone for a second round of elimination, i often end up actually eliminating all of them. Trust your feelings in the first round. and immediately put it up for randomization (pick 1 out of the semi-finals, entirely computer assisted.) The one it chooses, that's the one. You should have already sufficiently eliminated any that are actually wrong for any reason. so you must trust this choice. And do it! This means, because you're working with a list of mixed completion levels, in many cases you will have to first finish the writing. then get to the recording. in cases of 100%, go still do writing verification. open the files, think and consider it, decide if the 100% appraisal holds up. if it doesn't, know that you are required to make a decision 1 way or another as to how to finish it, if not already. Then record it. that's the only thing you work on until the recording is done. and remember, if you get hung up because you think you 'can't make it good enough', remember to finish it anyway and accept your bonus: which is you'll automatically be better next time. then continue to do recording and continue to do it until you start to feel like it's getting so good it makes you angry that not enough people are hearing it. then start opening up some social media accounts,

065101.question: 1.9.20 5:57 pm i don't understand your answer here at all and it's bothering me. would you mind ruining the joke by explaining this whole leg room situation?
065101.answer: if someone says 'waffles or pancakes', and nothing else, that is only a fragment of a question. they would need to say 'what' they are asking whether is pancakes or waffles. like if they showed me an item, and then said 'pancakes or waffles', then i would assumedly try to decide whether that item seems to be pancakes or waffles. Or, if they played me an audio sound, and then said 'pancakes or waffles', i would presumably be supposed to figure out if the sound is pancakes or waffles. When they say "pancakes or waffles", with absolutely no context, it presents a mostly impossible situation for me. so, given that the context is totally missing, sometimes rather than let the question hang frozen in contextlessness, i might make up my own context entirely, because they gave me absolutely nothing. so in this case, i made up the context as if the person was wondering which offered more leg room, pancakes or waffles, and also i made up the fact that the persons legs are quite small. so, in that way, i treated the horrible emptiness like a blank canvas. and i take blank canvases very seriously

065218.question: I noticed that your music references and recommendations rarely include songs from electronic music genres (trance, dubstep, chiptune, ambient, etc.) I was wondering if you listen to these types of songs, and if not then why. (No judgement, you can like what you like)
065218.answer: here is a great example of what makes genre names so tricky. you can use electronic sounds all you want in a 3 minute 'pop' song, that symbiotically meshes lyrics and music together in a way that hits hard and gets out (3 and a half minutes or less) ... you can drench that thing in electronics, but it will still probably be called 'pop'. It only tends to be called the names you mentioned when there is very little lyric and when it goes on for a long time. in which case its best use might be for some kind of accompaniment purposes. but regardless, i prefer not to discriminate towards or against electronics/computers. computers are a friend, i consider them just one of the many friendly assets of human life

065253.question: i wanna share some thoughts. when asked what is my religion, i usually try to reply that i have some personal spiritual practices. it's weird because the word religion has other connotations which have nothing to do with what i do, such as... community: what i do is completely personal and probably only makes sense to myself. i can share it with people i trust if i want to because it's important to me, but it's an individual practice. god, God or gods: i do have gods, but i don't think i treat them the same way as most religions do. the way i see it is, they exist in my mind but not in actual material reality, that would feel silly to me. anyway, i think you don't actually need gods for your religion or spiritual beliefs to exist, you can structure what is sacred to you in other types of images. it's when you end up symbolizing what's sacred to you as characters, that we usually end up calling them gods. or you can decide to cal l god th e whole reality itself, that might strike you as a sensible way of looking at the world. i feel like the question "what is your religion?" could be understood as "what is your truth?", and that is not something that may be simple to explain. damn, i think i gotta make my own blog/website soon. thanks for the inspiration

065258.question: 1.10.20 5:29 am it feels that way but that doesn't necessarily make it true..does an amoeba have free will? does a person with a tumor pressing on their brain causing them to have uncontrollable violent impulses have free will? i think we feel like we are in control because it's evolutionarily advantageous for us to feel that way, but really we are reactionary in nature. think of any movie right now...did you decide which movie to think of or did one just pop in your mind? i would argue everything is like that, including our deepest desires and values, that doesn't make our actions less valuable or important, it just means that ultimately, we as individuals are not the authors of our thoughts and actions, more like witnesses of them.

066220.question: when you talk about writing sessions does that usually mean sitting down and playing something to think of a melody, or putting something to a melody, or just whatever you think needs writing
066220.answer: construction of music recordings and videos is very intricate, and it's like building a house. This is not the part i refer to as the writing. the writing process i am referring to is entirely before any piece of contruction matierial is touced. before any of the actual audio recording / video contents are actually created. i must know how the song/video goes, completely. every word, every melody note, and every important chord. and the exact tempo, and the exact sequence, and the exact road map all the way until the end. and therefore as a by product of that i therefore also know almost exactly how long it will play. This still leaves room for tremendous amounts of detail. All the details really. the writing process is getting everything EXCEPT the details. That's because when you are constructing the house, (or making the recording, or creating the video graphics), there are SO MANY things to take care of and worry about, just in terms of what materials you use, what details to put, besically that's when the paint actually hits. There are so many things to deal with and worry about there, i have found out that you CAN NOT be unsure of *how the song goes*

066444.question: every time someone on here asks you what your favorite song you've made is you always respond with something like "I'd rather write a new better one" or something. I don't know if you need someone to tell you this, but it's absolutely reasonable to look back on the work you've done before and have pride in it. also, personally I don't see how anyone can even grow as an artist if they were to honestly never take any time to analyze their past work(s) of art and just kept plowing through the work process as if nothing even happened. seeing you grow as a songwriter over the years, I assume you've liked (and disliked) at least some of the songs you've made, in some ways

066473.question: What is a secondary dominant?
066473.answer: don't worry about it. those names are going to confuse the hell out of you. i don't recommend calling them that, and i think most people do not call them that. but anyway, you know how in songs, like in the key of C, you'll get G7 then C. like coming home, right. well, sometimes, you'll hear D7 before the G7, then C. try it. D7, G7, C. i think that's what they mean when someone says the first thing you said. but like i said, i don't call it that and don't know anyone who does, because the names don't really make any sense. well, the name 'secondary' does i suppose, but 'dominant' i think will throw people off. it's not dominating anything. it actually seems more like it's the final chord that dominates the whole thing, if you ask me

067578.question: I find myself in a conundrum often, where someone says something, and I can perceive (perhaps incorrectly) the type of reaction they want to get from saying said things. And it kinda shortcircuits my brain. where I happen to believe I know what they want to hear, yet I don't naturally tend towards that reaction. Which leaves me feeling like i let them down. Do you have any tips for dealing with those moments? Where you just want to react as you would, regardless of what you may assume is the desired response to their call. It's like I feel that i let them down whenever i dont give the response i believe they are looking for.
067578.answer: they might sense you are faking it. i can sense this sometimes when people do this to me they want to be talking to the real you. so the best thing you could possibly do is just be there with them in that moment. if you are unable to process what they said in any other way, blank stares are fine too, those can often produce a great deal of humor, among many other interesting things, as the time unfolds i personally feel let down and get a very empty feeling when it seems like someone is trying to tell me just what i want to hear. i want to be enthralled, confused, surprised, enriched, or even underwhelmed by something from them that i did not expect to hear. so in your situation, i would take every opportunity to avoid what you 'think' they 'want to hear.' if they really knew exactly what they wanted to hear, then there are some chat bots that would be a better fit for them

067593.question: Any advice on how to write music a bit more differently but in a good way? Especially when I listened to too much of mainstream stuff and being subconsciously influenced by them. Currently trying to compose more 'flexible' music but my ideas are always based on mainstream music (eg. melodies are always in a 8-bar structure etc.) and whenever I try to experiment around to get something different from conventional writing most of the time it would just sound cringy
067593.answer: this may not be what you want to hear, but you are going to find some music that you really enjoy which has the qualities you want. OR, if it does not exist, then you are going to have to invent something that's never been done before. so IF that is the case, then i would recommend finding things that you enjoy that seem inventive and new in other ways than the ways you might do, to at least familiarize with the fun and glory of being inventive. A good place to start if you hate all the music you've ever heard, is to start by deliberately trying to make something as different from that as possible, and then hone it in from there. you might have more fun than you expected

067734.question: hi bill! i want to start making videos, but i don't know what software i should use. i have tried using blender, but it is very confusing. lots of other software cost a decent amount of money. any advice on what to use?
067734.answer: yea, blender might be a little overwhelming as a first video program what you must do, for your very first video making experience, is: do NOT get a heavy program. do not get a big heavy huge expensive complex program. trust me, you will choke on brain fog and take a high amount of confused naps. What you must do is, use the absolute simplest thing you can get your hands on. like really simple. really really really simple. trust me, i have been through this, both ways, many times before. heck i am still going through it, especially throughout 2019 and 2020. You must use the most simple and basic thing you have. It's best to actually use something you already have, to further eliminate confusion and complications. Making videos is potentially the entire world at your fingertips. So that means you are going to have to take some desperate measures and precautions to NOT be overwhelmed at the start. staring at the whole universe of possibilities right at the start is enough to cause total brain failure. i wish i could tell you how many times i have been through both sides of this before. this is so important

068352.question: when arranging and recording instrumentation and stuff i often run into the problem of running through one option for a very long time trying to see if i like it or if it will work, only to at the end have spent maybe 2 hours on it and decide that i would rather not use that idea at all. something tells me that if i listened to my instincts early on about the idea i would know to dodge out and save myself the time and energy. despite that seeming like it should be intuitive this happens quite often. do you or have you experienced anything like this and do you have tips for getting out of that space as effectively as possible?
068352.answer: yes first, i would recommend you write quicker. that won't help for getting out of this situation, but it may help you not get into it. once you are in this situation, there is not much i can really recommend, although i guess the best thing you could do is probably look back to what your first idea was and religiously stick to that. because in this scenario, generally your trust/confidence levels will continue to go down, the longer you hang around. so the first idea is the one that is least likely to have been plagued with this problem. knowing that, sticking with that might be your best option

068407.question: Biggly advice time, how do you structure the planning of a video? I've been meaning to get a script down because I think I'm a bit of a funny feller, but I can't for the life of me plan individual tasks out. I've managed bigger projects before but something about writing a script seems difficult to organise Also being sad and lazy doesn't help but I'm almost over that.
068407.answer: yes, it is multiple mountains to climb, and i think i already have a good solution in mind for you, but i will keep reading yes, for you i recommend doing shorter projects. and then if you are still even slightly overwhelmed, then i would still recommend even shorter projects. if you don't believe me, check out the videos i was doing during 2014 and 2015. if i could have started with something like 'history of japan' first, believe me i would have. but i was going through the exact same thing as you. building a world is a mindfuck. it can be done, but you gotta work your way up. i personally am still working my way way up, there's a long way to go still. but yeah, if you want the secret to unlocking multiple huge mountains, the answer is to start brainlessly small and simple. this trick has worked for me over and over and over and over again, and i am doing it again now as we speak

068471.question: So, I usually write instrumental music. Y'know, programmatic/soundtracky kinda stuff. But right now I'm working on a song that requires lyrics. As it turns out, lyrics are fuckin' DIFFICULT. The music I usually write isn't very self-expressive; I'm more interested in seeing what I can bring to life in the mind of the listener by using different sounds, tones, and techniques. Writing lyrics feels more akin to public speaking. A very personal, intimate form of public speaking. I'm not used to communicating my thoughts so directly. I don't want to divulge too much of myself, but also I don't want my lyrics to be inane or cliche. Maybe I'm being too self conscious, or too aware of the hypothetical audience. In fact, I'm pretty sure that's it. Why is it that I always end up answering my own questions every time I go to ask them? Oh well, I'm still going to submit this one because I want to hear your thoughts.
068471.answer: that's true the funny thing is that you can use absolutely anything. there is so much room to do things that no one has ever done before. just to focus on the word side of things, for you what i would recommend is, open up a text file. and go bonkers every day for 3 meals on a regular basis. that's just to get in the mood. when it comes time to actually do musical lyrics, i recommend coming up with it musically. and if you have been going bonkers in the text lately, i think you will be on your best game, linguistically and otherwise

068690.question: I don't remember if this got asked before, but why was there such a long pause between "stuck in a rut" being uploaded to iTunes and your next single being put up? And how did "stuck in a rut" come about anyways? Given it's from all the way back in 2008 I'm curious the events surrounding it.
068690.answer: hm .... it seems like most of your information is wrong. 'stuck in a rut' the audio recording was made in 2005. it definitely wasn't put on itunes until at least 2015, because i didn't have the abilitiy to put things on itunes until then. but i hopefully dated it correctly, based on when it was made (2005). as of 2005 and the many years before that, i was fully capable of writing and recording instrumental music, but the whole 'words' part of it was really not figured out yet. 'i'm stuck in a rut' was essentially all i could fathom at that time. although meanwhile i was going absolutely bonkers via text editors. which i recommend to anyone who is trying to figure out which way is which. my strategy in general was to see if i could deconstruct the entire universe and how it works. that was just the only way i could get my head around the full game of songwriting, including any and all musical/linguistical things i thought i could and might be capable of. somewhere around 2009 i think i found myself ready to get into the full songwriting game, but it still took a few more years after that to get the recording schemes, and the writing schemes, further organized. videos, is yet an entirely separate piece of the puzzle which i had to sort of put together from scratch .... which i am actually doing again now, as it turns out

068929.question: Do you agree that scientists are underestimating how diverse life can be, by presuming water is essential to the formation of life rather than an energy gradient? Comparing Io to Europa, scientists assume Europa is more likely to host life because there is water there, but that water is likely completely homogeneous in temperature, providing little energy for any life, and even less places for that energy to go. Io is basically one large Yellowstone. Each of those geisers and vulcanic cauldrons has such a vast contrast in temperature that life may just fluke into existence like it did here. And those are in my opinion some of the less promising bodies. Jupiter herself is so vast and full of anomalies that there could very well be life in there, too. 069311.question: how do i figure out the chords in a song. i can't ever do it correctly it's so confusing
069311.answer: the very first step in building this skill is just learning to find individual notes. that is not how you will find chords once you are good at it, but it is really the only way to start training yourself. so my first question is, are you able to match a note you've heard, using an instrument? you are allowed to try as many times as you like, but let's say you hear a note. are you able to play notes on your instrument until you find the note that is the same note that you heard. this is a core basic skill you will need to have, and i suppose you can develop chord building very gradually from that starting skill

069408.question: building off that person's chord-finding question, what are your recommended next steps after achieving the skill of being able to play a note that you hear on your instrument? I can do that, but my issue with chords is that I'm never 100% sure whether the chord I've transcribed has too many notes or not enough. When I'm in the process of adding notes to the chord, there are definitely some that are obviously not present in the chord. Other notes however sound "good" but I wonder if they are actually there or are just "compliant" with the chord and are effectively coloring it in a way that sounds nice. As for not having enough notes in the chord, that is a mystery to me. Maybe that problem isn't as bad though because at a certain point you've gone through all the notes in the scale allotted to that chord in a certain range of the piano and hopefully any significantly lower/higher duplicates of those notes would be obvious to pick out.
069408.answer: don't include any notes you don't hear. after about 5 to 10 songs, you will suddenly start to 'get it.' after 100 to 1000 songs you will start to understand things even more. it's like learning a language. the first time you try to understand it you are definitely not going to get all the letters or even all the words. but if you spend enough time with it, eventually you will know it so well that you will be able to finish other people's sentences

069431.question: i love the word dang. it's the best non-curse curse word substitute (for damn) of which im personally aware. we can go through the others: frick, frig, shiz, heck, etc. heck is okayish but the rest are dumpster substitutions for babies exclusively -- because only people barred from the good stuff would feel obliged to reach for these extremely lesser knockoffs. nobody is ever going to take down king fuck. nobody's ever TRYING to come for ass, and all of its versatility (dumbass, badass, smartass). and it's not even that damn is bad. damn has its own incredibly powerful energy, bringing a unique severity and dare i say solemnity to the table. but dang manages to create a space for itself that goes beyond mere substitution. dang conjures an entire mythos of cowboys and fathers hitting their thumbs with hammers while trying to nail together wooden planks. "dangit" manages to be more than an avoided "damnit," a mere damnit-lite. there's such a vast am ount of beauty in the word dang that i truly don't understand. how did it get like this, do you think, bill? why can't the other fake curses do this well in the vernacular?

069495.question: is having a perfect pitch an innate skill or is it developed over time?
069495.answer: it has to be developed over a very short period of time, at an extremely young age. i should also mention that it is not important to good musicianship, and might likely distract from it. it also has a misleading name 'perfect pitch', because it has nothing to do with whether you can sing or play in tune. 'absolute pitch' might be a slightly clearer name for it. absolute pitch is mostly not at all what gives music its power. nearly 100% of the power of music comes from the relative relationships between pitches. and the good news is that those can be mastered at later ages, although it still helps to start young but it's not a deal breaker if you don't. where as with absolute pitch, you really can't get there unless you have it locked in by age 6. but as i said before, absolute pitch is hardly important for excellent musicianship, and might even be misleading or distracting
